ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would highly recommend the course to a fellow student.

I would recommend this course to a student who is deeply interested in ancient Egypt and/or art history. If you are interested in either of these topics, this class provides amazing opportunities to get hands on experience with objects in a museum setting and to read and write about objects.

Yes, I would definitely recommend it, although warn them that it's not going to be a survey of Egyptian Art. The students have the wonderful opportunity to pick and object from the MMA collection and conduct a study around them.
I would recommend this class, as it is a unique opportunity to have access to the artifacts in the Met, and develop techniques for interacting with artifacts.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The course provided with a wonderful array of theories, both general and specific to the study of Ancient Egypt. As my previous knowledge of Art history was mainly from books, it was a invaluable opportunity to discuss these issues with a curator whoworks around these subjects on a daily basis.

Taking this course as an undergraduate was a very good experience. I am seriously considering majoring in NELC with a concentration in Egypt, especially after taking this class. The work I did for this class gave me a great introduction to doing Egyptological research. I am interested in continuing such research, especially on my object.
This course gave me practice with approaching artifacts,as well as insight into new anthropological methods, which will help in my dissertation.
